Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: protected MSStickerView (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: public MSStickerView (MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGRect frame);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGRect frame) cil managed

Docs.param: Frame used by the view, expressed in iOS points.
Docs.summary: Initializes the MSStickerView with the specified frame.

remarks.para: This constructor is used to programmatically create a new instance of MSStickerView with the specified dimension in the frame. The object will only be displayed once it has been added to a view hierarchy by calling AddSubview in a containing view.
This constructor is not invoked when deserializing objects from storyboards or XIB filesinstead the constructor that takes an NSCoder parameter is invoked.

public static MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView.MSStickerViewAppearance Appearance { get; }
.property class MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView/MSStickerViewAppearance Appearance

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of MSStickerView.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of MSStickerView, they should use the method.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView.MSStickerViewAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn (Type[] containers);
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView/MSStickerViewAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of MSStickerView when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of MSStickerView, they should use the method.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public override IntPtr ClassHandle { get; }
.property instance native int ClassHandle

Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.

public static MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView.MSStickerViewAppearance GetAppearance<T> () where T : MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView;
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView/MSStickerViewAppearance GetAppearance<(class MonoTouch.Messages.MSStickerView) T>() cil managed

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of MSStickerView.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of MSStickerView.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of MSStickerView.
Docs.param: List of types that the developer wishes to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of MSStickerView that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of MSStickerView that has the specified trait collection when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works

example.code: var myTheme = MSStickerView.GetAppearance<MyMSStickerViewSubclass> (myTraits, typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); myTheme.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.
